articles.description:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct 27 (IPS) - In response to lawsuits brought by LGBTQI+ activists, the Mauritius Supreme Court has issued two landmark judgments striking down the criminalisation of consensual sex between adult men as unconstitutional. Its reasoning turned upside down the argument used by anti-rights forces to attack LGBTQI+ activists in many African countries: it acknowledged that criminalisation is the foreign import rather than gay sex, and a relic of colonialism it’s high time to shake off.

Read the full story, “Mauritius Begins to Correct a Historic Wrong Towards LGBTQI+ People”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Mauritius Begins to Correct a Historic Wrong Towards LGBTQI+ People

"There is no grass or fodder to feed them," says Fermina Quispe, a Quechua farmer from a rural community located at 4,200 meters above sea level.

Read the full story, “Community Solutions Combat Water Shortages in Peru's Highlands”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Community Solutions Combat Water Shortages in Peru's Highlands

articles.description:
SAINT LUCIA, Oct 26 (IPS) - A new report by the University lists six areas of grave concern and states that in the absence of behavior and priority change, the world could face catastrophe in areas like groundwater depletion and species extinction.Melting mountain glaciers. Unbearable heat. An uninsurable future. Space debris. Groundwater depletion. Accelerating extinctions. The United Nations University Institute for Environment and Human Security said this week that these six environmental "tipping points" can have "irreversible, catastrophic impacts for people and the planet."

Read the full story, “Human Action Pushing the World Closer to Environmental Tipping Points, UN University Warns”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Human Action Pushing the World Closer to Environmental Tipping Points, UN University Warns

articles.description:
Oct 26 (IPS) - On December 4, 2019, landslides in the Bududa region of Uganda killed 20. The landslides occurred after heavy rains, and a Red Cross report estimated that 96 households were affected, with 49 houses destroyed. It displaced many, while others continued to live in high-risk areas that could "slide at any moment."

Read the full story, “Uganda: When Climate Justice Becomes Climate Justice Denied”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Uganda: When Climate Justice Becomes Climate Justice Denied

articles.description:
AMMAN, Jordan, Oct 26 (IPS) - For the first time since the beginning of a war that claimed the lives of over 220,000 people, a senior Houthi delegation travelled from Yemen to Saudi Arabia’s capital Riyadh in mid-September.

Read the full story, “A Tug of War and Peace in Yemen”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A Tug of War and Peace in Yemen

articles.description:
Much of the damage caused by the destruction of Ukraine’s Kakhovka dam in June is “irreversible”, with likely changes to the environment that impact ecosystems and human health.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Ukraine dam disaster update, childcare investment, healthcare under fire in Sudan”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Ukraine dam disaster update, childcare investment, healthcare under fire in Sudan

articles.description:
Experts with deep experience across government, the private sector, technology, civil society, and academia have been tasked with supporting UN efforts to ensure Artificial Intelligence (AI) is used for the greater good of humanity.

Read the full story, “New UN Advisory Body aims to harness AI for the common good”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: New UN Advisory Body aims to harness AI for the common good

articles.description:
Progress has been made in advancing a 2019 peace agreement in the Central African Republic (CAR ) but the support of the international community is still vital, the UN Special Representative Valentine Rugwabiza told the Security Council on Thursday.

Read the full story, “International support critical to forge lasting peace in Central African Republic”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: International support critical to forge lasting peace in Central African Republic

articles.description:
The United Nations General Assembly on Thursday morning, in New York, is holding an emergency special session on the Israel-Palestine conflict, amid a continuing deadlock at the Security Council, and conditions in the besieged enclave of Gaza growing more dire by the hour. Follow this page for live updates...

Read the full story, “UPDATING LIVE: UN General Assembly convenes emergency meeting on Gaza”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UPDATING LIVE: UN General Assembly convenes emergency meeting on Gaza

articles.description:
Day 19 of the Gaza conflict comes on the heels of the deadliest 24 hours so far amid hospitals shutting down, while UN humanitarians reiterated urgent calls on Thursday for all civilians to be protected and hostages released.

Read the full story, “Israel-Palestine: Gazans ‘left with nothing but impossible choices’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Israel-Palestine: Gazans ‘left with nothing but impossible choices’

articles.description:
TOKYO, Japan, Oct 25 (IPS) - The world and the Middle East do not need another violent conflict. This is a region that has experienced far too much violence over the years. Hamas’ desperate attacks on innocent civilians was intended to provoke an Israeli overreaction that would, among other things, jeopardise Israeli diplomatic negotiations with the Gulf States and Saudi Arabia and create generalised anxiety within Israel. It was also aimed at demonstrating Hamas’ military capacity and vengeance for years of a humiliating blockade of Gaza. Kidnapping Israeli civilians was callous and brutal but part of a plan to use hostages as bargaining chips around the release of Palestinian prisoners in Israel.

Read the full story, “The Hamas-Israel Conflict”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Hamas-Israel Conflict

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
CIPHER BRIEF REPORTING – As supporters of Lebanon’s Shiite Muslim political party Hezbollah bury dozens of militants killed in small-scale clashes with Israeli soldiers since [...] More 
The post What Happens if Hezbollah Makes Good on its Vow to Escalate Violence in the Middle East? appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: What Happens if Hezbollah Makes Good on its Vow to Escalate Violence in the Middle East?
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: The WHO and Unicef have expressed concern over the safety of their staff and humanitarian partners in Gaza. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus called for protection of civilians and full humanitarian access, while Unicef executive director Catherine Russell highlighted the safety concerns for children in Gaza. United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned of a potential collapse of the humanitarian system in Gaza, affecting over 2 million civilians. Israel has expanded its military campaign against Hamas, leading to increased tensions and a communication blackout in the region.
articles.title: We have lost touch with our staff, health workers in Gaza: WHO Chief

articles.description: Law enforcement in Maine continues its search for Robert R. Card, the suspected shooter responsible for the mass shootings in Lewiston that killed 18 people and injured 13. The search, which included executing search warrants in the neighboring town of Bowdoin, has so far been unsuccessful in locating Card. The town of Lewiston and surrounding communities have been on lockdown as authorities conduct their search. Card, a US Army reservist, had previously been committed to a mental health facility.
articles.title: Maine manhunt for Lewiston mass shooter extends to another night

articles.description: The names of five people found shot to death in a North Carolina home have been released by the sheriff's office. The victims were found dead from gunshot wounds and their names were announced by the Sampson County sheriff's office. The authorities are investigating the incident and have identified some people of interest. It is unclear whether the case is being treated as a mass killing. This incident comes just hours after another shooting in Maine, making it the 36th mass killing in the US this year.
articles.title: Sheriff names 5 people fatally shot in southeast North Carolina home

articles.description: The onePulse Foundation has announced that it is dropping its plans to build a museum to honor the victims of the 2016 massacre at a gay nightclub in Florida. The foundation cited financial concerns, including soaring construction costs and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the city of Orlando is still moving forward with constructing a memorial for the victims. The efforts to build a memorial and museum have been slow, with the nightclub's owners only recently agreeing to sell the property.
articles.title: Museum plan for Florida nightclub massacre victims dropped as Orlando moves forward with memorial

articles.description: Italian authorities have captured footage of the leaders of Italy's three most powerful organized crime groups - the Ndrangheta, Camorra, and Cosa Nostra - sharing a meal, raising concerns of a potential alliance. Prosecutors believe that these once-rival criminal organizations have set aside their differences to form a grand alliance, exploiting business opportunities in Italy's prosperous north. The mafia groups have shifted their focus to white-collar crime and legitimate investments, funneling drug trafficking profits into various sectors.
articles.title: Super Mafia: Rising concerns as Italy's top three gang godfathers seen sharing meal

articles.description: President Joe Biden met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in a conversation seen as a precursor to a potential meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month. The meeting aimed to explore the possibility of stabilizing the tense relationship between the two countries amidst conflicts in Ukraine and Israel. Biden emphasized the need for responsible competition management and cooperation in addressing global challenges. The meeting was viewed positively, and Biden expects to meet with Xi again.
articles.title: Biden talks with Chinese foreign minister as he prepares for potential meeting with Xi

articles.description: Hamas has stated that it is prepared for an invasion of the Gaza Strip by Israel after air strikes have cut off communications in the area. Israel has announced that it is extending its ground operation in response. The military has significantly increased its strikes, leading to intense bombardment in northern Gaza. Hamas has responded with rocket fire. All internet connections and communications in Gaza have been cut, according to Hamas, who accused Israel of doing so to enable "massacres".
articles.title: Hamas says 'ready' for Israel invasion of Gaza

articles.description: Internet and phone services in Gaza have collapsed due to intensified Israeli bombardment, leaving the 2.3 million people in the strip cut off from the outside world and each other. The Israeli military's announcement of "expanding" ground operations signifies a potential all-out invasion of Gaza. This has led to a blackout in internet and communication services, exacerbating the already dire situation for Palestinians, who are huddled in homes and shelters with dwindling supplies of food and water.
articles.title: Israeli air and ground strikes intensify in Gaza; internet collapse cuts territory off from outside

articles.description: Supermodel Bella Hadid, who is of Palestinian descent, has spoken out about the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict, expressing her support for the Palestinian cause and condemning attacks on civilians. Hadid also revealed that she has been receiving death threats daily since her personal phone number was leaked. She emphasized the need for leaders to uphold the laws of war and called for pressure to be placed on them to address the urgent needs of the people of Gaza.
articles.title: 'Generational trauma of my Palestinian blood': Bella Hadid's plea for peace in Middle East

articles.description: House Republicans, led by Rep. Anthony D'Esposito, have introduced a resolution to force a vote on the removal of Rep. George Santos from Congress. Santos is facing numerous charges related to fraud and financial offenses. The resolution highlights Santos' history of promoting false information about himself and his campaign. A vote on the resolution is expected next week. Santos has admitted to inaccuracies in his personal history but has resisted calls to resign.
articles.title: House Republicans seek vote to remove George Santos over falsehoods

articles.description: A new "Siberian Battalion" has been formed by Russian nationals who have defected from Putin's army to fight alongside Ukrainian forces in the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine. The battalion includes prominent members such as Alexei Makarov and Ildar Dadin. The exact location and impact of the battalion remain undisclosed, but their presence could complicate matters for Putin's forces, who have already suffered significant losses in the conflict.
articles.title: Siberian battalion: The new Ukraine unit formed of entirely of Russians

articles.description: House Speaker Mike Johnson expressed concerns about President Biden's cognitive decline after their meeting. Johnson emphasized that this observation was not a personal insult to the President and mentioned the differences between Biden's past performances and recent speeches. The meeting revolved around Biden's request for aid to Ukraine, Israel, and other projects. Johnson confirmed that his caucus did not approve of packaging foreign aid together and advocated for separating these issues.
articles.title: 'Everyone ages differently': Newly-elected Speaker Mike Johnson on Biden's cognitive decline

articles.description: Hamas has conditioned the release of hostages in Gaza to a ceasefire in Israel's bombardment of the Palestinian enclave, which was launched after a deadly attack on southern Israel. Israel says it is preparing a ground invasion, but has been urged by the US and Arab countries to delay in order to avoid civilian casualties. Two US fighter jets struck weapons and ammunition facilities in Syria in retaliation for attacks on US forces by Iranian-backed militias.
articles.title: Release of hostages needs ceasefire, Hamas official says

articles.description: Europe News: Russian forces heavily shelled the centre of the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson on Friday, injuring a number of people and damaging at least 10 bu.
articles.title: Russians shell Ukraine's Kherson, damage and casualties reported

articles.description: US third-quarter earnings estimates for S&P 500 companies are more positive than previously expected, with a projected increase of 4.3% compared to the same period last year, according to LSEG data. This estimate has increased from the previous forecast of a 2.6% gain. The results are based on reports from half of the S&P 500 companies and estimates for the rest. Despite concerns over rising US Treasury yields, investors are closely watching third-quarter earnings following a decline in the second quarter.
articles.title: Third-quarter US earnings now seen growing 4.3% year-on-year -LSEG data

articles.description: An independent commission in Spain has estimated that over 200,000 minors have been sexually abused by the Roman Catholic clergy since 1940. The report, which surveyed over 8,000 people, found that 0.6% of Spain's adult population said they had suffered sexual abuse by members of the clergy as children. Including abuse by lay members, the percentage rises to 1.13%. The commission also interviewed 487 victims who highlighted the lasting emotional impact of the abuse. The report criticizes the Catholic Church's response, calling for the creation of a state fund to compensate victims.
articles.title: Spanish clergy sexually abused over 2,00,000 children, probe estimates

articles.description: An alliance of ethnic rebel groups in Myanmar has launched a coordinated offensive to seize military targets in areas near the Chinese border. The Arakan Army, Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army, and the Ta'ang National Liberation Army, known as the Three Brotherhood Alliance, have initiated "Operation 1027" in Myanmar's Shan state. The groups aim to safeguard civilians, assert their right to self-defense, and respond to ongoing attacks by the military government.
articles.title: Alliance of 3 ethnic rebel groups carries out coordinated attacks in northeastern Myanmar

articles.description: Pakistan's former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, faced criticism in the Senate for allegedly making sexist remarks at a rally. Sharif attacked women from the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party for dancing at their rallies, which led to opposition and calls for him to be taught how to "respect women." This incident echoed a similar incident involving former chief of Muttahida Qaumi Movement, Altaf Hussain. Sharif's remarks were seen as sexist and misogynistic, with critics highlighting his belief that only his daughter, Maryam, should be involved in politics.
articles.title: Pakistan's former PM Nawaz Sharif under fire for using sexist remarks against PTI women supporters

articles.description: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan, currently in jail, has expressed concerns about his safety and alleged that there could be an attempt on his life through slow poisoning. Khan also criticized the caretaker government and accused them of granting reliefs to his political rival, Nawaz Sharif. He claimed that the cases against him are politically motivated and aimed at keeping him in jail. Khan urged the people to fight for their rights and the freedom of the country. He also directed his lawyers and party officials to prepare for the upcoming elections.
articles.title: 'They will make another attempt on my life...through slow poisoning': Imran Khan's message from jail

articles.description: US fighter jets conducted airstrikes on two locations in eastern Syria connected to Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps in response to recent attacks on US bases and personnel in the region. The strikes aim to deter future aggression while avoiding further escalation. The targeted sites were chosen because they store munitions used in the attacks against the US. Syrian opposition activists confirmed the strikes, and casualties are yet to be determined. Iran-backed groups have retaliated with rocket attacks on a US base in Syria and an attempted drone attack on an airbase in Iraq.
articles.title: US fighter jets strike Iran-linked sites in Syria in retaliation for attacks on US troops

articles.description: US President Joe Biden said on Wednesday he has "no confidence in the number that Palestinians are using" for the death toll in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip, where the health ministry says at least 7,028 people have been killed in Israeli attacks. Biden was asked at a White House press conference whether the death count, which the ministry says includes some 2,913 children, meant Israel was ignoring US appeals to reduce civilian deaths in its bombardment of the coastal enclave.
articles.title: Biden says has 'no trust' in Hamas' Gaza death count as 'toll tops 7,000'

articles.description: Israel has announced that it will provide compensation for ships that are damaged due to the war in Gaza. The government is also taking steps to minimize risks for vessels using the country's ports. Israel relies on its seaports for trade and basic needs, and compensation will be awarded for "war damage" caused to Israeli or foreign vessels. Additional war risk insurance premiums have increased for ships calling at Israeli ports, and some vessels have diverted to the north.
articles.title: Israel to pay compensation for ships damaged in Gaza war

articles.author: Surendra Singh
articles.description: Russian atomic energy corporation Rosatom has set a new record by installing a research reactor pressure vessel in Bolivia, making it the world's highest nuclear facility. The project, built on behalf of the Bolivian Agency for Nuclear Energy, will allow Bolivia to conduct scientific research and develop various economic sectors. The reactor will also produce radioisotopes and serve as a training tool. The project also includes a cyclotron complex and a laboratory, with completion expected in 2025.
articles.title: Russia nuclear agency Rosatom sets up world’s highest nuclear facility in Bolivia

articles.description: EU leaders have called for pauses in Israeli bombing and Hamas rocket attacks in order to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza. The leaders expressed grave concern for the deteriorating humanitarian situation and called for continued, safe, and unhindered access to reach those in need. While EU leaders have condemned Hamas' attack, they have struggled to present a unified message, with some emphasizing Israel's right to self-defense and others expressing concern for Palestinian civilians.
articles.title: EU leaders urge pauses in Gaza bombing to get aid in

articles.description: Tasneem Ismael Ahel, a 19-year-old college student in Gaza City, has become a voice in the midst of war, using WhatsApp voice notes to share the challenges faced by Palestinians in the conflict-ridden region. Her audio messages provide insight into the daily struggles of living under siege, including the fear of bombings and the scarcity of essential supplies. Despite the hardships, Tasneem remains resilient and dreams of studying dentistry abroad. Her message transcends the conflict and offers hope for a better future.
articles.title: 'Maybe it’s my last voice': Gaza teenager's audio diary captures life under bombardment

articles.description: The Beatles are set to release a 'new' record, titled "Now and Then," on November 2. The song was originally written and sung by John Lennon and has been completed with the assistance of artificial intelligence. The track, often referred to as the last Beatles song, offers a unique opportunity to hear the band working together again, long after their split in 1970. The use of AI in music remains a subject of industry-wide debate.
articles.title: The Beatles to release final track with AI help

articles.description: A British Conservative MP has been arrested on suspicion of rape and possession of controlled substances, according to police. The MP, Crispin Blunt, confirmed his arrest and stated that he is ready to cooperate with the investigation. Blunt has been suspended by his party and now sits as an independent in the House of Commons. This is the latest scandal to hit the struggling UK ruling party, which has faced several allegations of misconduct in recent years.
articles.title: British MP arrested on suspicion of rape

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Pakistan's interim government has urged illegal immigrants, including Afghan refugees, to return voluntarily or face arrest and deportation after an October 31 deadline. The move has been met with criticism from Afghan authorities and international bodies. Holding centres have been established in various locations to ensure the safe return of immigrants.  Geo-fencing has been implemented to identify areas with illegal immigrants, and a reward has been offered for information on their whereabouts after November.
articles.title: Leave or face action, Pakistan tells Afghan refugees

articles.description: France is facing an ecological challenge as bark beetles invade the forest of La Teste-de-Buch, which was previously damaged by wildfires. The beetles infest weakened pine trees, laying their eggs in the bark and causing the trees to die. Efforts to combat the infestation include tree removal, but experts warn that if nothing is done, the situation will worsen in the future. The beetle infestation has even spread to urban areas, requiring the removal of pine trees from residents' gardens.
articles.title: 'Time bomb': Tree-killing bugs threaten France's lush forests

articles.description: An Iranian court has ordered the US government to pay $420 million in compensation to victims of a failed 1980 operation to free hostages held at the US embassy in Tehran. The operation, known as Operation Eagle Claw, ended in disaster after encountering sandstorms and mechanical problems. The judiciary's Mizan Online news agency reported that during the operation, US forces had "attacked" a bus carrying Iranian passengers. This comes after previous multi-billion dollar compensation awards against Tehran by US courts.
articles.title: Iran court orders US to pay damages for 1980 hostage rescue bid

articles.description: Taliban authorities have released education activist Matiullah Wesa, who was detained for seven months. Wesa had been an advocate for girls' education in conservative rural areas of Afghanistan. His release came after condemnation from the UN and rights groups. The Taliban administration has restricted access to education for girls and women since taking control of the country in 2021. Wesa's organization, Pen Path, confirmed his release, and actress Angelina Jolie had previously called for his release in an open letter.
articles.title: Prominent Afghanistan education activist released by Taliban

articles.description: The Chief Election Commissioner of Bangladesh has expressed concerns about the upcoming polls in January, stating that a favorable environment has not been achieved yet. He warned that if there are voting irregularities, the entire election process could be suspended and new elections organized. Tensions have been escalating in the capital city of Dhaka, with simultaneous rallies announced by the ruling and opposition parties. Major Western nations, including the United States, have called for fair and credible polls in Bangladesh.
articles.title: Top Bangladesh election official warns of poll suspension in case of voting irregularities

articles.description: Hurricane Otis hit Mexico's beach resort city of Acapulco as a category 5 storm, causing at least 27 deaths and leaving the city in a state of disaster. The storm brought winds of 165 miles per hour, cutting off communications and road links with the region. President Lopez Obrador had to abandon his vehicle and walk to the scene due to blocked roads. Residents described the destruction of buildings, looting, and the struggle to find food and shelter.
articles.title: Hurricane Otis leaves at least 27 dead in Mexico's Acapulco

articles.description: Governor of Maine, Janet Mills, expressed her condolences after a tragic mass shooting in Lewiston, stating that no city or state deserves such violence. The shooting took place at a bar and bowling alley, resulting in at least 18 deaths and 13 injuries. The primary suspect, Robert Card, is still at large, prompting a massive search. Schools were canceled, and residents were advised to stay indoors. President Joe Biden ordered flags to be lowered to half-staff as a mark of respect for the victims.
articles.title: City did not deserve this terrible assault on its citizens: Governor on Maine mass shooting

articles.description: The Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister, Oleksandr Kubrakov, has denied reports that the new Black Sea export corridor has been suspended. Ukrainian and British firms had reported that Ukraine had suspended use of the corridor due to a possible threat from Russian warplanes and sea mines. However, Kubrakov stated that all available routes established by the Ukrainian Navy are valid and being used by civilian vessels. The corridor was launched in August as a "humanitarian corridor" to bypass the de facto blockade in the Black Sea after Russia quit a U.N.-brokered deal.
articles.title: Ukraine says its Black Sea grain corridor is working

articles.description: A US-Russian journalist, Alsu Kurmasheva, has been charged by Russia for failing to register as a "foreign agent." This move by Russian authorities has been criticized by rights groups as an escalation of their campaign against independent media. Kurmasheva is the second US reporter to be detained in Russia this year. If convicted, she could face up to five years in prison. Critics argue that the law is overly broad, allowing Russian law enforcement to arrest journalists at will.
articles.title: Russia formally charges detained US-Russian journalist

articles.description: Arab countries including the United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Qatar, Kuwait, Egypt, and Morocco have condemned Israel's targeting of civilians and violations of international law in Gaza. They argue that Israel's right to self-defense does not justify neglecting the rights of Palestinians. The ministers also criticized forced displacement and collective punishment in Gaza, emphasizing the need for a two-state solution with an independent Palestinian state. Both the West Bank and East Jerusalem, captured by Israel in 1967, should be part of this solution.
articles.title: Arab countries condemn 'flagrant violations' in targeting civilians in Gaza

articles.description: Maria Corina Machado has been declared the winner of an opposition-organized primary in Venezuela to choose a presidential candidate. The voting, which drew over 2.4 million voters, was denounced by the government as illegitimate. Despite government doubts and a ban on Machado running for office, the opposition commission declared her the winner with 93% support. Voters expressed their hopes for a change in government to address the country's complex crisis.
articles.title: Maria Corina Machado is winner of Venezuela opposition primary that government has denounced

articles.description: US News: ROUND LAKE BEACH: A man who allegedly attacked two relatives with a sledgehammer in suburban Chicago was fatally shot by police after he charged at of.
articles.title: Police in Illinois fatally shoot sledgehammer-wielding man after reported domestic assault

articles.description: Special counsel Jack Smith is seeking potential legal action against Donald Trump if he continues discussing witnesses in the federal election case. The prosecutor has requested a stricter gag order on Trump, including the possibility of imprisonment if violated. This comes after Trump hinted on social media that a potential witness might be labeled as a "weakling" and "coward" if he testified in exchange for immunity. Despite potential consequences, Trump's defiance of gag orders may continue to appeal to his voting base.
articles.title: Prosecutor Jack Smith seeks jail time for Trump's witness remarks

articles.author: Mariana Alfaro
articles.description: Former president Barack Obama warns in an online post that any Israeli military strategy “that ignores the human costs could ultimately backfire.”
articles.title: Obama urges Israel to minimize civilian casualties in war with Hamas

articles.author: Kelly Kasulis Cho, Niha Masih, Jennifer Hassan, Annabelle Timsit, Claire Parker, Miriam Berger, Noga Tarnopolsky, Sammy Westfall, Ben Brasch
articles.description: The two hostages, Yocheved Lifshitz, 85, and Nurit Cooper Yitzhak, 79, were released and sent to a hospital, according to a statement from the Israeli government.
articles.title: Israel-Gaza war live updates: Airstrike kills scores of Palestinians, authorities say; Hamas releases two hostages

articles.author: Ana Herrero, Samantha Schmidt, María Paúl
articles.description: Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian government promised a competitive election next year, but opposition nominee María Corina Machado is still barred from running.
articles.title: Venezuelans back candidate to challenge Maduro — if she’s allowed

articles.author: Miriam Berger, Noga Tarnopolsky, Marc Fisher
articles.description: Airstrikes hit across the Gaza Strip, including in the southern areas where the IDF told Palestinians to evacuate for their own safety.
articles.title: Israeli forces intensify airstrikes on Gaza; more hostages are released

articles.author: Michael Birnbaum
articles.description: Officials in Washington hope that talks with China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi could see Beijing use its influence to pressure Iran not to join the Israel-Hamas fight.
articles.title: China’s top diplomat to visit D.C. amid tensions over South China Sea, Israel

articles.author: Susannah George, Sufian Taha
articles.description: Israel’s escalating raids and arrests in the West Bank are an extension of its war against Hamas in Gaza, but analysts say the crackdown could fuel militant activity.
articles.title: West Bank militancy surges as Israel steps up raids and arrests

articles.author: Matthew Cappucci
articles.description: Forecasters are monitoring Hurricane Tammy in the Atlantic while Otis is set to become the fourth tropical storm to make landfall in Mexico this month in the Pacific.
articles.title: Tropical storms and hurricanes still roam the Atlantic and Pacific

articles.author: Martine Powers, Ted Muldoon, Rennie Svirnovskiy
articles.description: An episode guide: Grenada’s Prime Minister was executed in a coup in 1983. The location of his remains is unknown. New details reveal the role the U.S. played.
articles.title: ‘The Empty Grave of Comrade Bishop’: Podcast episode guide

articles.author: Greg Miller, Isabelle Khurshudyan
articles.description: The CIA has built up Ukraine’s espionage capabilities, but U.S. officials stress that the agency has no involvement in targeted killings operations by Kyiv
articles.title: Ukrainian spies with deep ties to CIA wage shadow war against Russia

articles.author: Terrence McCoy
articles.description: The question of responsibility for the 2006 Gol Flight 1907 crash, then Brazil’s deadliest aviation disaster, divided the Western Hemisphere’s largest nations.
articles.title: Brazil blames U.S. pilots in crash that killed 154. They’re still flying.

articles.author: Kyle Melnick
articles.description: Distance, a Paris running store, told customers they could steal items if they outran the security guard: Méba Mickael Zeze, one of France’s fastest sprinters.
articles.title: A store let customers steal shoes — if they could outrun a pro sprinter

articles.author: Ishaan Tharoor
articles.description: Politicians and diplomats are seeing American greenlight in Israel’s pounding of Gaza, and call into question an apparent double standard that President Biden’s rhetoric can’t mask.
articles.title: Israel’s bombing of Gaza undercuts the West’s Ukraine moralism

articles.author: Samantha Schmidt, David Feliba
articles.description: Economy Minister Sergio Massa and Libertarian lawmaker Javier Milei advanced in the first round of voting Sunday to a runoff election Nov. 19.
articles.title: For president, Argentina to choose between anger and fear

articles.author: Danielle Douglas-Gabriel, William Wan
articles.description: Rockville native and Israeli reservist Omer Balva ‘brought a lot of light to the world.’
articles.title: He rushed from Maryland to Israel to fight. On Friday, he was killed.

articles.author: Brittany Shammas, Niha Masih, Kelly Kasulis Cho, Leo Sands, Jennifer Hassan, Paulina Villegas, Ben Brasch
articles.description: Border watchmen were injured by Israeli tank fire, Egyptian military authorities said Sunday. The Israel Defense Forces said it “regrets the incident.”
articles.title: IDF apologizes for blast at Egyptian border post; U.S. senators visit Tel Aviv

articles.author: Karen DeYoung, John Hudson, Dan Lamothe, Abigail Hauslohner, Yasmeen Abutaleb
articles.description: In the days after the Hamas invasion, the White House deployed the president’s top diplomats and military advisers in a frantic, prolonged mission to stave of a worst-case scenario of a wider Middle East conflict.
articles.title: How the Biden administration tried to slow Israel’s invasion of Gaza

articles.author: Christian Shepherd, Lyric Li
articles.description: Beijing has wasted no time weighing in on the conflict, trying to bolster its status as a champion of developing countries and as a rival to the United States.
articles.title: Where China stands on the Israel-Gaza war and what it stands to gain

articles.author: Noga Tarnopolsky, Rick Noack
articles.description: “What we’re seeing is a prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region,” Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Sunday.
articles.title: Hezbollah steps up attacks, IDF says, fueling fears of wider conflict

articles.author: Hazem Balousha, Miriam Berger, Claire Parker
articles.description: Fuel was excluded from the first aid shipment to Gaza since the war began. The shortage has exacerbated an already dire humanitarian crisis.
articles.title: Gaza gets some aid — but no fuel — as power crisis upends lives

articles.author: Leo Sands
articles.description: Another potential flash point is Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, where there is a risk of a second front opening up between Israel and Hezbollah.
articles.title: Why are Israel and Hamas at war? A basic explainer.

articles.author: Jennifer Hassan, Niha Masih
articles.description: At least 23 journalists have been killed in the Israel-Gaza war since Oct. 7; the majority of those killed so far, 19, were Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
articles.title: Journalists killed in the Israel-Gaza war: A look at the lives lost

articles.author: Francesca Ebel, Isobel Koshiw
articles.description: The strike was the latest attack to kill civilians in the Kharkiv region near the Russian border.
articles.title: Russian strike hits mail facility in Ukraine’s Kharkiv, killing 6

articles.author: Claire Parker, Kelsey Ables, Andrew Jeong, Frances Vinall, Leo Sands, Victoria Bisset, Hazem Balousha, Justine McDaniel, Miriam Berger, Dan Rosenzweig-Ziff
articles.description: Israel plans to increase its strikes on Gaza City “to minimize the dangers to our forces in the next stages of the war,” the Israel Defense Forces spokesman said.
articles.title: Israel-Gaza war live updates: Israel to increase strikes on Gaza; IDF chief says ‘the enemy is preparing’

articles.author: Loveday Morris, Steve Hendrix
articles.description: A Hamas document lists instructions on operating weapons, identifies vulnerabilities in Israeli military equipment and offers tips on killing with a knife.
articles.title: Documents found on fighters reveal Hamas capabilities, bloody plans

articles.author: David Nakamura
articles.description: Uri Raanan said he hopes to be reunited soon with daughter Natalie, 17, who was freed by Hamas militants after 13 days in captivity.
articles.title: Biden hails freed U.S. hostages as family awaits reunion

articles.author: Kareem Fahim
articles.description: Small but influential, Qatar again flexes its role as a regional mediator.
articles.title: In Gaza war, Qatar revisits role as regional mediator

articles.author: Claire Parker, Rick Noack, Yvonne Wingett Sanchez
articles.description: World leaders and diplomats attempted to build momentum for sustained humanitarian relief during a summit in Cairo.
articles.title: Israel says it will step up attacks as first aid convoy reaches Gaza

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.description: Owen Farrell hailed England's versatility as the team survived a "scrappy game" to beat Argentina 26-23 to claim third place at the Rugby World Cup on Friday.
articles.title: Farrell hails England's versatility after Argentina 'scrap' to finish third at World Cup

articles.description: While the international media have no access to the Gaza Strip, Gazans themselves, both civilians and professional journalists, continue to report on the situation on the ground, risking their lives in the process. The FRANCE 24 Observers team spoke to one of them.
articles.title: 'I haven't seen my wife or my children': The Gazan journalists reporting on life under the bombs

articles.author: Annette YOUNG
articles.description: As Israel's war with Hamas continues, thousands have been killed as the region teeters dangerously on the edge of a wider conflict that could result in direct US and Iranian involvement. At a moment when peace seems so incredibly far away, where does this leave women peace activists on both sides? Annette Young talks to Dr Yael Braudo-Bahat from Israel's Women Wage Peace and Palestinian activist Nivine Sandouka from the Alliance for Middle East Peace; both are calling for an immediate end to the bloodshed.
articles.title: Palestinian and Israeli women activists call for end to bloodshed

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: US President Joe Biden met China's foreign minister for talks on Friday as the two countries seek to smooth ties ahead of a possible visit by Chinese leader Xi Jinping.
articles.title: Biden meets Chinese FM, calls for cooperation on 'global challenges'

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Over 200,000 minors are estimated to have been sexually abused in Spain by the Roman Catholic clergy since 1940, according to an independent commission published Friday.
articles.title: Spanish probe estimates more than 200,000 children abused by Roman Catholic clergy

articles.author: James ANDRE
articles.description: FRANCE 24 brings you the stories of the people who are on the front lines of climate change. From Kenya to Panama via Greenland and Australia, our reporters James André and Achraf Abid went to meet the Indigenous people who live in harmony with nature and whose daily lives are being turned upside down by global warming. Don't miss our series of four special reports. In this second episode, we take you to Greenland.
articles.title: Indigenous people and climate change: With the Inuit when the ice melts (2/4)

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: A year ago Elon Musk purchased X, formerly known as Twitter, taking the platform on a journey that has resulted in lost money, advertisers and trust.
articles.title: One year after Musk's Twitter takeover, X still beset by turmoil

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Russia said on Friday that it had thwarted a Ukrainian drone attack near a nuclear plant in the country's south, where two news outlets said an explosion had damaged the facade of a warehouse storing nuclear waste.
articles.title: Russia says it thwarted a Ukrainian drone attack near its Kursk nuclear plant

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Police in Maine extended their round-the-clock search for suspected Lewiston mass shooter Robert R. Card into the early hours of Friday morning, as the U.S. Army reservist eluded a manhunt following the bar and bowling alley massacres that killed 18 people and wounded 13 more.
articles.title: Manhunt for Maine mass shooter extends to second night

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Guyana on Thursday announced a "significant" new oil discovery in an area claimed by neighbouring Venezuela and said it had awarded bids to eight companies, foreign and local, to drill for crude in its waters.
articles.title: Guyana greenlights oil drilling in waters claimed by Venezuela

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Former Premier Li Keqiang, China’s top economic official for a decade, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 68.
articles.title: Former Chinese PM Li Keqiang dies of heart attack

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: EU leaders on Thursday failed to convince Kosovo and Serbia to make a breakthrough in the protracted push to normalise ties between the two Balkan neighbours.
articles.title: European Union fails to pressure Kosovo and Serbia to end standoff

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: At the assembly’s resumed emergency special session on Israeli actions in the Palestinian territories Thursday, speaker after speaker backed the Arab resolution’s cease-fire call – except for Israel’s UN Ambassador Gilad Erdan, who told the 193-member world body, "A cease-fire means giving Hamas time to rearm itself, so they can massacre us again." Follow our live blog as the day's events unfold. All times are Paris time (GMT+2).
articles.title: 🔴 Live: Palestinians beg UN to 'stop the bombs', Israel insists Hamas must be 'obliterated'

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Last year, ferocious wildfires destroyed thousands of hectares of one of France's most picturesque forests. Now French authorities are battling an invasion of beetles that are devouring the weakened pines of La Teste-de-Buch, in the southwestern region of Gironde.
articles.title: Foresters race against time as tree parasites destroy French woods

articles.description: Since the attack carried out on Israel by Hamas on October 7, the internet has been flooded with thousands of images of the conflict and even more rumours. However, many of the videos and photos circulating are actually false. Two of these images recently went viral. The first image supposedly shows a camp for Israeli refugees illegally constructed in Palestinian territory. The second is said to show a Palestinian flag being held aloft by football fans. In reality, both of the images were generated by AI.
articles.title: AI-generated images add to the confusion in the war between Israel and Hamas

articles.author: Bahar MAKOOI
articles.description: The Iranian regime has launched an online campaign to recruit volunteers – including children – to fight alongside Hamas in the war against Israel. But the government’s propaganda efforts are not making much headway among anti-regime Iranians.
articles.title: Iran’s Revolutionary Guard recruits volunteers to fight in Gaza

articles.author: Marc PERELMAN
articles.description: In an interview with FRANCE 24 on Day 20 of the Israel-Hamas conflict, a spokesman for Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas called on the Biden administration "to pressure Israel to stop this war". Nabil Abu Rudeineh also said that the current conflict was "an opportunity for us, for the Israelis, for the Europeans and the Americans" to reach a "two-state" solution in the Middle East.
articles.title: 'US should pressure Israel to stop war in Gaza,' Abbas spokesman tells FRANCE 24

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Slovakia's new populist Prime Minister Robert Fico said Thursday that his government was stopping military aid to Ukraine, in the first Western reversal of the kind.

articles.description: Even before war broke out, Israel’s southern city of Ashkelon was frequently targeted by Hamas rockets fired from Gaza. But now, the number of strikes has soared and some 30 percent of the city’s population has left for safer parts of the country. Our team on the ground went to meet those who have stayed and find out just how they are coping with life under almost constant bombardment.

articles.description: EU leaders agreed at a summit on Thursday to call for the establishment of "humanitarian corridors and pauses" to get urgently-needed aid into Gaza. The news came after Hamas on Thursday released a list of almost 7,000 names of Gazans it said had been killed in Israeli strikes after the US president cast doubt on its toll figures. articles.title: US auto workers union reaches tentative deal with Ford to end strike

articles.author: David Badash, The New Civil Rights Movement
articles.description:
A Rolling Stone report detailing Donald Trump's alleged plan for NATO if he wins the White House next year is making political experts greatly concerned.
"Trump and his team are actively planning to pull the United States out of NATO — or, barring that, kneecap the collective defense provisions at the heart of the alliance," writes Rolling Stone editor-in-chief Noah Shachtman.
"As this, and the damning tapes of Trump/Pratt conversation show, Donald Trump is the biggest internal threat to America's national security we have had since the Civil War," warns political scientist Norman Ornstein of The Atlantic, pointing to the Rolling Stone piece and the revelations about Trump's remarks to an Australian national in which he allegedly divulged U.S. nuclear submarine secrets.
"Donald Trump wante…
articles.title: Trump’s reported plan for NATO makes him ‘biggest internal threat to national security’

articles.author: David Edwards
articles.description:
During a press conference in Israel on Monday, Cohen noted that he was both an American and Israeli citizen. And he thanked Graham for supporting Israel. Graham is in Israel as part of a bipartisan US Senate delegation.

	"But it starts at home," Cohen said. "And I'd like to ask any Democrat senator here that would like to speak to Rashida Tlaib. She still has a tweet up condemning Israel for a hospital attack."
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?

	"We are here together, not to talk about the problems at home, which are many," Graham shot back.


	"You're not going to screw this up!" Graham shouted.


	"Get this guy out of here!" Graham exclaimed.


	"I'm an American," Graham said, pounding on the podium.

READ MORE: Trump's Georgia racketeering trial could happen 'sooner than he expected': Ex-prosecutor

	"And I believe in free speech," Graham continued. "I don't believe what the squad has to say at all. But I came here with Democrats and Republicans to let everybody in the world know."


	Graham later apologized after his temper cooled.


Watch the video below from Newsmax.
articles.title: 'Get this guy out of here!' Lindsey Graham blows up at Newsmax reporter in Israel

articles.author: Brad Reed
articles.description:
Former President Donald Trump is pushing for a major American foreign policy change in his second administration that would likely upend decades of global national security infrastructure.
Sources tell Rolling Stone that Trump is planning to pull the United States entirely out of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance unless it caves to his demands that include one that would seem to undermine the entire purpose of the alliance.
In addition to his standard calls for other NATO countries to chip in more for their defense spending, Trump also reportedly wants to rip up the strategic doctrine that an attack on one NATO country represents an attack on all NATO countries.
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"When he was in office, Trump would repeatedly scoff at this collective-defense clause of the North Atlantic Treaty, known as Article 5," the publication writes. "One former senior administration official recalls to Rolling Stone a moment in the Oval Office in mid-2018 when the then-president started reading from a written list of smaller NATO countries, some of which he argued most Americans had never even heard of before."
Tearing up Article 5 would be a major boon for the likes of Russia, which attacked non-NATO member Ukraine in 2022 but notably has not attacked other NATO members on its border such as Estonia and Latvia.
Dr. Aaron Stein, a Black Sea Fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute, tells Rolling Stone that Trump's plan would be a "tremendously stupid endeavor" and added that "trading away allies based on ignorance, and Trump is ignorant about this issue, is just silly for broader U.S. national security."
articles.title: Trump plots 'tremendously stupid' NATO plan for his second term: report

"We are concerned at the possibility of Iranian proxies escalating their attacks against our own personnel, our own people," Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on CBS News. "We expect there is a likelihood of escalation."
"No one should take advantage of this moment to escalate to further attacks on Israel or, for that matter, attacks on us on our personnel."
Blinken said the United States, which has sent two carrier groups to the eastern Mediterranea…

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The organiser of the Web Summit, one of the tech sector's leading events, announced his resignation Saturday following a backlash over his online posts following the Hamas attacks on Israel.
"Unfortunately, my personal comments have become a distraction from the event," Paddy Cosgrave of Ireland explained in a brief statement sent to AFP.
"I sincerely apologize again for any hurt I have caused," added the co-founder of the tech mega gathering created in 2009 in Dublin but held in Lisbon since 2016.
A spokesperson for the organization said: "Web Summit will appoint a new CEO as soon as possible, and Web Summit 2023 in Lisbon will go ahead as planned."
This year's edition from November 13 to 16, is set to bring together some 2,300 startups and more than 70,000 participants, say organizers.
Several companies, including tech giants Google and Meta, which is behind Facebook and Instagram, as well as event headliners have announced they are boycotting the gathering since Cosgrave's remarks.
He had written on X, formerly Twitter, that he was "shocked at the rhetoric and actions of so many Western leaders & governments" in support of Israel.
"War crimes are war crimes even when committed by allies, and should be called out for what they are," he wrote on October 13.
Since shock Hamas attacks on Israel on October 7, which left 1,400 dead, Israel has launched devastating air and ground bombardments of Gaza. The Hamas authorities say 4,385 people have died.
The boycott by Meta and Google followed other exits by companies and tech figures, including Intel, Siemens and US comedian Amy Poehler and X-Files actor Gillian Anderson.
articles.title: Web Summit chief resigns after Israel comments furor

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
A first anniversary in office is normally a moment for a leader to celebrate, but Britain's Rishi Sunak hits the milestone this week with a mountain to climb to retain power in a general election expected next year.

Two by-election losses to the main opposition Labour Party on Thursday underscored how Sunak, 43, has failed to revive the Conservatives' beleaguered fortunes during his first 12 months in charge.
"The more people see of Sunak, the less they like him in some ways," Tim Bale, author of a book about the right-wing Conservatives since Brexit, told AFP.
"He doesn't really project authority, he doesn't necessarily give the impression that he's in control of events.
"He looks, in part, as if he's sort of lurching from one policy initiative to another in a desperate attempt to curry …
articles.title: Sunak nears first anniversary as UK PM with little to celebrate

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Aboriginal Australian leaders ended their vow of silence on Monday to denounce millions of their compatriots for rejecting a landmark push for Indigenous rights, saying that the referendum result would be "etched into Australia's history forever".
Simmering racial divisions were exposed earlier this month when just over 60 percent of Australians voted against a referendum to acknowledge Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders within the 1901 constitution.
In the wake of the result, many Indigenous leaders embarked on a "week of silence", asking for time to grieve what they saw as a crushing rejection at the hands of Australia's white majority.
Some leaders ended that silence in a scathing open letter addressed to the government, criticizing the "appalling and mean-spirited" outlook of milli…
articles.title: Indigenous Australians denounce 'shameful' referendum result

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
A teenage Iranian girl, who fell into a coma earlier this month following an alleged encounter with officers over violating the country’s hijab law, is said to be "brain dead", Iranian state media reported on Sunday.
"Follow-ups on the latest health condition of Armita Geravand indicate that her health condition as brain dead seems certain despite the efforts of the medical staff," the Islamic Republic of Iran News Network said.
Iranian authorities have denied claims by rights groups that the 16-year-old was hurt after a confrontation on Oct. 1 with officers enforcing the mandatory Islamic dress code in the Tehran metro.

The report on Geravand could revive nationwide protests sparked by the death of 22-year-old Kurdish Iranian woman Mahsa Amini last year in the custody of morality police.
(Reuters)
articles.title: Iranian teenage girl ‘brain dead’ after alleged encounter with morality police over hijab

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Hurricane Norma slammed into Mexico's northwestern coast Saturday afternoon as a Category 1 storm, bringing dangerous rain and flooding, authorities said.
The storm came ashore about 25 kilometers (15 miles) northwest of the resort city of Cabo San Lucas on the Baja California coast, gradually weakening from a Category 3 as it approached land.
Norma was moving northeast at 9 kph, packing winds of up to 130 kph, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) reported at 2100 GMT. 
Norma was expected to bring rainfall of up to 45 centimeters (18 inches), producing "flash and urban flooding, along with mudslides in areas of higher terrain," the NHC said.
"Life-threatening surf and rip current conditions" would affect the coast of southwestern and west-central Mexico and Baja California Sur for the next couple of days.
Hotel employees in Cabo San Lucas urged guests to stay indoors until authorities give the all-clear, Gustavo Matamoros, a hotel worker, told AFP.
Local authorities say about 60,000 tourists are staying in the area, most of them international visitors.
Footage from Milenio TV showed flooded streets as Norma arrived. No casualties have been reported by authorities.
Norma should continue to weaken to a tropical storm as it moves toward the west coast of Mexico on Sunday.
Two people died last week when Hurricane Lidia struck the western states of Jalisco and Nayarit.
© Agence France-Presse
articles.title: Hurricane Norma makes landfall in Mexico as Category 1 storm

articles.author: Reuters UK
articles.description: By Leigh Thomas PARIS (Reuters) - Governments should open a new front in the international clampdown on tax evasion with a global minimum tax on billionaires, which could raise $250 billion annually, the EU Tax Observatory said on Monday. If levied, the sum would be equivalent to only 2% of the nearly $13 trillion in wealth owned by the 2,700 billionaires globally, the research group hosted at the Paris School of Economics said. Currently billionaires' effective personal tax is often far less than what other taxpayers of more modest means pay because they can park wealth in shell companies she...
articles.title: A global effort to stop billionaire tax evasion could earn $250 billion: study

Brent crude futures fell 67 cents to $91.49 a barrel, as of 0203 GMT, having lost $1.02 to $91.14 a barrel earlier in the session. U.S. West Texas Intermediate crude futures lost 72 cents to trade at $87.36 a barrel, after sliding $1.72 to $87.03 a barrel earlier on Monday. The contracts had risen more than 1% las...

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
Israel bombarded Gaza with air strikes early on Monday and its aircraft struck southern Lebanon overnight, as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu convened a meeting of his top generals and his war cabinet to assess the escalating conflict. 
Israel's attacks concentrated on the Gaza Strip's centre and north, Palestinian media reported. A strike on a house near the Jabalia refugee camp, in northern Gaza, killed several Palestinians and wounded others, according to media reports.
articles.title: Israel strikes Gaza, Lebanon overnight; Netanyahu convenes generals

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
BUENOS AIRES (Reuters) — Argentina's general election vote was being counted on Sunday evening, with early signals suggesting the under-fire Peronist ruling coalition was performing better than expected, while all eyes remained on far-right libertarian radical Javier Milei. 
Argentines flocked to the polls on Sunday to vote in a tense national election where wild-haired outsider Milei has hogged the limelight amid the country's worst economic crisis in two decades and rising anger with the traditional elite.
articles.title: Argentina election vote count underway as run-off looks likely

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
A secret recording revealed by "60 Minutes Australia" exposed a conversation former President Donald Trump had with billionaire Anthony Pratt while he was in office, The New York Times reported. 
Pratt is the businessman whom the ex-president told classified secrets that are of the highest possible security level. Another thing Trump revealed is a detail from the call he had with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky in late 2019 that ultimately led to his first impeachment. 
Among the notes of the call, Trump told Zelensky that he would release the military equipment already allocated by Congress if and only if he did a "favor" for him. 


Declassified text of Trump's Ukraine call notes

            Photo: Scren capture
        



Trump bragged to Pratt: “That was nothing compared to what I usually do," admitting not only to the bribery but also that it's frequent behavior for him. 

"It is not clear whether Mr. Pratt shared these accounts with prosecutors or whether prosecutors are aware of the recordings," The Times reported. 
Another thing included in the report is that Trump asked his wife Melania to strut about Mar-a-Lago in a bikini. Another revelation is that behind closed doors Pratt was trashing Trump, even while he was still in office. 
Senate Republicans ultimately refused to hear beyond the opening statements of the Trump impeachment, voting to acquit him of the charges. 
Read the full report here.
articles.title: Trump told a friend the 'perfect' Ukraine call was 'nothing compared to what I usually do'

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
New court documents reviewed by the New York Times reveal Donald Trump's Australian pal, Anthony Pratt, told a lot of people about life at Mar-a-Lago post-presidency. Among the things he said, involved trashing Trump behind his back. 
Pratt, the Australian billionaire that Trump revealed classified information to, told around 45 people about the classified info as well as a number of things about his presidential pal.  
Not only did Trump tell his wife, Melania, to strut around the property in a bikini, but Pratt paid Trump tens of thousands of overages for ticket prices for events at the country club. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"Another witness told prosecutors about hearing uncorroborated reports that Mr. Pratt spent $1 million for tickets to a Mar-a-Lago New Year’…
articles.title: Secret recording reveals Australian billionaire pal was trashing Trump behind his back

Gómez played for Sevilla last season, but had since signed for AC Monza in Italy. The player has called in a lawyer. He won the Wor...

articles.author: David Edwards
articles.description:
While appearing on ABC's This Week, host Jonathan Karl pressed Scott on his claim that U.S. "weakness" led to the terrorist attacks.

POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?be allowed to run for office?


	The candidate pointed to the Biden administration's decision to release $6 billion in Iranian funds.


	But Scott also acknowledged that Iran never received any of the money because the Biden administration froze it.


	"And to say that Joe Biden is complicit, which you also said, in the greatest, deadliest attack on the Jewish people since the Holocaust, I mean, that's beyond the pale, isn't it?" the ABC host asked.


	"There's no doubt that when you have President Biden negotiating with the Iranians for the release of hostages, I said this under President Obama as well, when we paid 400 million dollars for hostages, you were creating a market for American lives to be lost," Scott opined.


	Watch the video below from ABC or at the link. .

articles.description:
An IDF spokesperson has claimed Israeli troops plan to “dismantle totally” all of Hamas’ military infrastructure in Gaza. 

Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus told Sky News Australia the country was involved in a war it “did not start”. 

“It started by Hamas crossing into our communities and butchering more than one thousand of our civilians," he said.  

“In response to that we are going to dismantle, totally, all of the military infrastructure in Gaza which facilitated this attack and we are going to dismantle Hamas from ever being capable of doing it again.” 

The Lieutenant’s comments follow a targeted ground raid by Israel’s military in northern Gaza on Thursday. 

A wider offensive is expected.

articles.author: Amos Fox
articles.description:
With Israel’s looming ground offensive against Hamas, and considering the population density of Gaza, urban warfare will certainly be a significant component of the conflict. Urban warfare in Gaza will not be a deft war of maneuver, but rather a slow, methodical grind of attrition. The Israel Defense Forces’ relatively small size in relation to the population density and urban sprawl of Gaza will strip away many of the Israeli military’s inherent asymmetries. Moreover, two additional factors will increase the voracity of urban warfare. First, due to Gaza’s small size, there is almost no land available to fight a war
The post Urban Warfare, Sieges, and Israel’s Looming Invasion of Gaza appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: Urban Warfare, Sieges, and Israel’s Looming Invasion of Gaza

articles.author: Leo Blanken
articles.description:
Welcome to Rewind & Reconnoiter. Each week, we’ll ask one of our authors to look back at an article they’ve written for War on the Rocks in light of a current news event. Did their argument hold up? Read more below to find out. *** In 2018, Leo Blanken, Kai Thaxton, and Michael Alexander wrote “Shock of the Mundane: The Dangerous Diffusion of Basic Infantry Tactics” for War on the Rocks, in which they argued that “the marginal improvement of tactical prowess in violent non-state groups may lead to outcomes that have strategic implications for global U.S. counter-terrorist and counter-insurgent operations.”
The post Rewind and Reconnoiter: Hamas and the Dangerous Diffusion of Basic Infantry Tactics, with Leo Blanken, Kai Thaxton, and Michael Alexander appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: Rewind and Reconnoiter: Hamas and the Dangerous Diffusion of Basic Infantry Tactics, with Leo Blanken, Kai Thaxton, and Michael Alexander

articles.author: Emma Salisbury
articles.description:
Submarines are an integral part of the U.S. Navy’s future force design, and rightly so. The United States needs more submarines if it is to deter China in the Indo-Pacific, particularly given the Chinese navy’s growing undersea fleet. But the question remains — can America build and maintain the number of submarines it needs?  The end of the Cold War gave rise to a balancing act within the world of U.S. naval acquisitions — how to make cuts under falling defense budgets while retaining a sufficient industrial base for the future. The cancellation of the SSN-21 Seawolf program in 1992
The post The Sinking Submarine Industrial Base appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: The Sinking Submarine Industrial Base

articles.description: Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease, or EHD, is typically found in the tropics and affects cattle, deer and other animals. It's rarely fatal, but ranchers are concerned for their animals and livelihoods.

articles.description:
Time: Biden Cast Doubt on Gaza’s Death Toll. Palestinian Officials Responded With 6,747 Names 
In the past three weeks, more than 1,400 people in Israel and 7,000 Palestinians have been killed amid fighting between Israel and Hamas. That is, if you believe the casualty figures coming out of the region. This week, U.S. President Joe Biden suggested that the Palestinian death toll in Gaza, which has been under heavy bombardment by Israel following Hamas’ Oct. 7 massacre, is not to be trusted. 
“I’m sure innocents have been killed, and it’s a price of waging a war,” Biden said at a press conference on Wednesday. “But I have no confidence in the number that the Palestinians are using.” The President didn’t offer further evidence for his skepticism of the Palestinian health ministry's data, which the U.S. State Department has cited both internally and publicly, in the latter case as recently as March. (When asked to provide evidence to support Biden's statement, the White House referred TIME to comments made by U.S. National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby, who on Thursday reiterated the President’s assertion that the death toll cannot be taken “at face value” because the “Gaza Ministry of Health is just a front for Hamas.”) 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: This is the current death toll .... Ministry: At least 7,000, including 2,913 children, killed in Israeli strikes on Gaza (AFP). 
More News On The Accuracy Of Casualty Numbers From Gaza

 
What is Gaza’s Ministry of Health and how does it calculate the war’s death toll? (AP)
 
Despite Biden's doubts, humanitarian agencies consider Gaza toll reliable (Reuters)
 
Gaza health ministry publishes list of war dead as credibility attacked -- UPI
articles.title: Are Gaza's Casualty Numbers Accurate?

Bloomberg: House Will Consider Ukraine, Israel Aid Separately, Johnson Says 
(Bloomberg) -- The House of Representatives will consider new military assistance for Ukraine and Israel as separate measures, the newly installed speaker said Thursday, complicating President Joe Biden’s attempts to secure support for both US allies. 
“Our consensus among House Republicans is that we need to bifurcate those issues,” Speaker Mike Johnson told Sean Hannity of Fox News. He said he delivered that message to White House officials after meeting with Biden earlier in the day. 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: As it should be.

articles.title: US Congress Will Consider Ukraine, Israel Aid Separately

articles.description:
Ukrainian servicemen prepare to fire at Russian positions from a U.S.-supplied M777 howitzer in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on July 14, 2022. VOA has learned the U.S. will provide up to $150 million in additional military aid for Ukraine as soon as Oct. 25, 2023. 

VOA: Exclusive: $150 Million in Ukraine Military Aid Expected Wednesday 
PENTAGON — The United States is providing up to $150 million in additional military aid for Ukraine in a package expected as soon as Wednesday, three U.S. military officials tell VOA, a week after Ukraine used its newest weapon from the United States to pummel Russian military targets deep into Russian-controlled eastern Ukraine. 
The package includes more GMLRS rockets for High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems (HIMARS), munitions for the National Advanced Surface-to-Air Missile System (NASAMS), TOW anti-tank missiles, AIM-9 Sidewinder missiles and 155 mm rounds, according to two of the officials who spoke to VOA on condition of anonymity to discuss the package prior to its announcement.

 
Read more ....

 
Update #1: US to supply Ukraine with new $150 million military aid package (Ukrainska Pravda) 
Update #2: US Announces New $150Mln Military Package for Ukraine, Including NASAMS, AIM-9M, Stinger Missiles (Sputnik)

 
WNU Editor: I am not surprised that the U.S. is sending more military aid to Ukraine. I am surprised that it is only $150 million.
articles.title: U.S. Sending More Military Aid To Ukraine

A pair of delegations from Iran and Hamas have descended on Moscow, where Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov’s subordinates are huddling with Israel’s enemies as the war in Gaza threatens to expand. 
“The talks focused on the recent Israeli aggression on the Gaza Strip and the strategies to halt Israeli crimes, which are backed by the U.S. and many Western nations,” Hamas announced on its English-language Tele…

Reuters: 900 US troops heading to Middle East to bolster defenses as attacks surge 
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - About 900 more U.S. troops have arrived in the Middle East or are heading there to bolster air defenses for U.S. personnel amid a surge in attacks by Iran-affiliated groups, the Pentagon said on Thursday.
As tensions soar over the Israel-Hamas war, U.S. and coalition troops have been attacked at least 12 times in Iraq and four times in Syria in the last week, Pentagon spokesperson Brigadier General Patrick Ryder told reporters. 
A total of 21 U.S. forces have suffered minor injuries, the vast majority of them traumatic brain injuries.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: One source that I trust is saying that two more US aircraft carrier strike groups are going to be deployed to the Middle East in the coming days. This will make a total of 4 US aircraft carrier strike groups being deployed to the Middle East. 

If true, this is not a deployment to deter other actors to get involved in the Israel - Hamas war, this is a deployment to strike a major target.
articles.title: More US Troops Heading To Middle East

articles.description:
The Tonnerre ship can carry helicopters, armored vehicles, tanks and troops | Laura Kayali/POLITICO

 

Politico: The EU prepares for war — and this French ship is the tip of the spear 
France’s powerful amphibious helicopter carrier is a floating village with gyms and a boulangerie … plus missiles, machine guns, landing craft, choppers and tanks. 
ABOARD THE FRENCH HELICOPTER CARRIER TONNERRE — John Denver’s "Country Roads," a folk song from 1971, resounds through the Tonnerre. 
It’s 7:30 a.m., and some of the crew aboard the Mistral-class amphibious helicopter carrier are already eating breakfast — loading up on coffee, bread and jam ahead of a planned exercise to storm a Spanish beach. It's been a short night, and plans for the landing have changed several times. 
The French assault vessel — 199 meters long, 32 meters wide and able to carry 21,500 metric tons — is a key element in the European Union’s first live military exercise in October off the southern coast of Spain.  
Read more ....

CNBC: U.S. GDP grew at a 4.9% annual pace in the third quarter, better than expected 
* Gross domestic product, a measure of all goods and services produced in the U.S., rose at a 4.9% annualized pace in the third quarter, ahead of the 4.7% estimate. 
* The sharp increase came due to contributions from consumer spending, increased inventories, exports, residential investment and government spending. 
* While the report could give the Fed some impetus to keep policy tight, traders were still pricing in no chance of an interest rate hike when the central bank meets next week.
The U.S. economy grew even faster than expected in the third quarter, buoyed by a strong consumer in spite of higher interest rates, ongoing inflation pressures, and a variety of other domestic and global headwinds.

* Footage shows the elaborate tunnels Palestinian Islamist fighters are using 
* Heavily armed militants can be seen navigating the tunnels 
* Missiles, machine guns, ammunition and rocket propelled weapons are visible 
Chilling footage has emerged showing the elaborate tunnel systems that Hamas terrorists have been using to move weapons, hostages and stage attacks on Israel. 
The footage gives insight into the claustrophobic conditions the Palestinian Islamist fighters have been operating in. 

It shows militants using metal rods and shovels to dig the tunnels. 
Many of them appear to be quite cramped and dark with footage showing the fighters slightly slouching as they move through the tunnels guided by headtorches.
